    • AIMS weather time series data sets

AIMS weather time series data sets

Source: vignettes/weather.Rmd
weather.Rmd

This example assumes you have obtained an AIMS Data Platform API Key. Further details about API Key implementation and usage can be found here.

To interact locally with this example in RStudio, click on the source code at the top of this page, then click on Raw, and simply copy and paste the code to a new .Rmd file created in RStudio.

Let’s start by loading some packages that we are going to need down the track:

library(plyr)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)

Once you have obtained your API Key, please consider following the recommended guidelines as explained here. If you successfully placed your API Key permanently to the .Renviron, then just set the object my_api_key to NULL in the chunk below. If for some reason you are having difficulty placing your API Key permanently to the .Renviron, then just paste it to the object my_api_key.

# set my_api_key to NULL if successfully placed in .Renviron
# paste your key where it says api-key-for-r-notebook
my_api_key <- "api-key-for-r-notebook"

Install R Client

dataaimsr can be installed and loaded directly from GitHub using the following code:

install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("https://github.com/AIMS/dataaimsr")
library(dataaimsr)

Discover a dataset

Suppose we want to query a data series and plot it then the procedure might be:

  1. Examine documentation and establish query filters
  2. Perform data download using aims_data
  3. Use the Rpackage ggplot2 to create a time-series chart

There are two types of data programs currently available through the AIMS Data Platform API: Weather, which contains multiple datasets for different variables (e.g. Air Temperature, Air Pressure, Chlorophyll, and many others), and Sea Water Temperature Loggers, which contains multiple datasets of (you guessed it!) sea water temperature at different sites and water depths. They are queried via unique DOI identifiers.

For the purposes of this example, we will query the AIMS Weather. To explore this data program, we use the function filter_values. This function takes a DOI and a given parameter filter, and returns all the available information regarding the filter. For the Weather data sets, a list of available filter parameters can be found here. We recommend exploring the parameter series:

weather_doi  <-  aims_data_doi("weather")
filter_values(weather_doi, filter_name = "series") %>%
  head()
##   series_id
## 1      9847
## 2    104918
## 3    100686
## 4       266
## 5      2639
## 6     10243
##                                                              series_name
## 1      Cleveland Bay North Cardinal Marker Minimum Wind Speed 10 Minutes
## 2        Myrmidon Reef Weather Station Wind Speed (scalar avg b 10 min) 
## 3                            Saibai Island Weather Station Hail Duration
## 4 Orpheus Island Relay Pole 3 Wind Direction (Vector Average 30 Minutes)
## 5 Hardy Reef Weather Station Wind Direction (Vector Standard 10 Minutes)
## 6                           Raine Island Weather Station Air Temperature

The benefits to choosing a data series is that it comes from one location and variable type, making the data easy to plot. If we did not choose a data series from the AIMS Weather program, we would have to specify additional parameters to ensure the data is as expected.

Finally our values and filters might look like the following:

Variable Value Description
doi 10.25845/5c09bf93f315d DOI for AIMS Weather found here
series 64 Found here, Davies Reef Air Temperature data series
from-date ‘2018-01-01’ We want to start charting on 1/1/2018
thru-date ‘2018-01-10’ We are plotting 10 days of data

Query and Plot Dataset

After deciding on query parameters, we plug the series id into a aims_data function:

davies <- aims_data(weather_doi,
                    api_key = my_api_key,
                    filters = list("series" = 64,
                                   "from-date" = "2018-01-01",
                                   "thru-date" = "2018-01-10"))

The object davies is a list containing four elements:
- metadata a doi link containing the metadata record for the data series
- citation the citation information for the particular dataset - links the link returning the data query
- data an output data.frame

We can even visually compare multiple series at once. For instance, let’s compare the air temperature data from Davies Reef and Bramble Cay for the same period of time:

target_series <- c("Davies Reef" = 64, "Bramble Cay" = 87929)
results <- plyr::llply(target_series, function(series_number, my_api_key, ...) {
  aims_data(weather_doi, api_key = my_api_key,
            filters = list("series" = series_number, ...))
}, my_api_key = my_api_key, "from-date" = "2018-01-01", "thru-date" = "2018-01-10")

weather_data <- plyr::ldply(results, "[[", "data")

ggplot(weather_data) +
  geom_line(aes(x = time, y = raw_value, colour = site_name)) +
  labs(x = "Date",
       y = "Air temperature (˚C)",
       colour = "Site",
       title = "AIMS",
       subtitle = "Weather stations") +
  theme_bw() +
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text(size = 12),
        axis.title.y = element_text(size = 12),
        legend.position = "bottom")

Bibliography

plyr::ldply(results, "[[", "citation") %>%
  dplyr::rename("citation" = "[[") %>%
  dplyr::select(citation) %>%
  unlist %>%
  unname
## [1] "Australian Institute of Marine Science (AIMS). 2009, Australian Institute of Marine Science Automatic Weather Stations, https://doi.org/10.25845/5c09bf93f315d, accessed 27 May 2020.  Time period: 2018-01-01 to 2018-01-10.  Series: Davies Reef Weather Station Air Temperature"
## [2] "Australian Institute of Marine Science (AIMS). 2009, Australian Institute of Marine Science Automatic Weather Stations, https://doi.org/10.25845/5c09bf93f315d, accessed 27 May 2020.  Time period: 2018-01-01 to 2018-01-10.  Series: Bramble Cay Weather Station Air Temperature"
